H0.text: Genes control inherited traits in organisms, a statement that best supports Barbara McClintock’s 1931 discovery that genes could change position on a chromosome, as demonstrated by corn plants where moving a gene next to the kernel‑color gene produced kernels of various colors.

H1.text: Corn plants can reproduce in laboratory environments, allowing researchers in 1931 to observe that genes can change position on a chromosome, as demonstrated when a gene moved next to the kernel‑color gene in corn produced kernels of various colors.

H2.text: Chromosomes can move around in the nucleus of a cell, a phenomenon Barbara McClintock discovered in 1931 when she showed that genes could change position on a chromosome and, in corn plants, moving a gene next to the gene that controls kernel color caused kernels of various colors on an ear of corn.

H3.text: Genes are able to disappear and reappear in later generations is the statement that best supports Barbara McClintock’s 1931 discovery that genes can change position on a chromosome, demonstrated in corn plants where moving a gene next to the kernel‑color gene produced kernels of various colors.

A4.text: In early 1948, she made the surprising discovery that both Dissociation and Activator could transpose, or change position, on the chromosome.

A5.text: She observed the effects of the transposition of Ac and Ds by the changing patterns of coloration in maize kernels over generations of controlled crosses, and described the relationship between the two loci through intricate microscopic analysis.
